raw_text:
US top of supercomputing charts
 
 The US has pushed Japan off the top of the supercomputing chart with IBM's prototype Blue Gene/L machine.
 
 It is being assembled for the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, under the US Department of Energy. IBM test results show that Blue Gene/L has managed speeds of 70.72 teraflops. The previous top machine, Japan's NEC Earth Simulator, clocked up 35.86. The Top 500 list was announced on Monday and officially charts the fastest computers in the world.
 
 It is announced every six months and is worked out using an officially recognised mathematical speed test called Linpack which measures calculations per second.
 
 Once completed in 2005, Blue Gene/L will be more powerful than its current prototype. "Next year with the final Blue Gene, four times what it is this year, it is going to be a real step up and will be hard to beat," said Erich Strohmaier, one of the co-founders of the Top500 list. It will help scientists work out the safety, security and reliability requirements for the US's nuclear weapons stockpile, without the need for underground nuclear testing. It will also cut down on the amount of heat generated by the massive power, a big problem for supercomputers.
 
 In second place was Silicon Graphics' Columbia supercomputer based at the US space agency's (Nasa) Ames Research Center in California. The Linux-based machine was reported to have reached a top speed of 42.7 trillion calculations per second (teraflops) in October. It will be used to model flight missions, climate research, and aerospace engineering. The defeated Japanese contender, the Earth Simulator, which was listed in third place, losing the top spot it had held since June 2002. It is dedicated to climate modelling and simulating seismic activity.
 
 Since the first supercomputer, the Cray-1, was installed at Los Alamos National Laboratory, US, in 1976, computational speed has leaped 500,000 times. The Cray-1 was capable of 80 megaflops (80 million operations a second). The Blue Gene/L machine that will be completed next year will be five million times faster. Started in 1993, the Top 500 list is decided by a group of computer science academics from around the world. It is presented at the International Supercomputer Conference in Pittsburgh.
llama3.2:1b:
US top supercomputing charts, surpassing Japan's NEC Earth Simulator with IBM's Blue Gene/L machine.

The US Department of Energy will assemble and test the machine for the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.

Blue Gene/L has reached 70.72 teraflops, a significant speed increase over previous machines.

It will be used to simulate climate research, aerospace engineering, and other scientific applications, cutting heat generated by the power source.

The Earth Simulator, Japan's top contender, lost its position after reaching a top speed of 35.86 trillion calculations per second.

This is the first time a US supercomputer has topped the list since the Cray-1 in 1976.
llama3.2:3b: The US has pushed Japan off the top of the supercomputing chart with IBM's Blue Gene/L machine, which has achieved speeds of 70.72 teraflops. The previous top machine, NEC Earth Simulator, clocked up 35.86. The Top 500 list was announced and is updated every six months using a mathematical speed test called Linpack. The US machine will be used to analyze nuclear weapons stockpiles and reduce heat generated by supercomputers.
gemma2:2b: The US has taken the top spot on the supercomputing chart with IBM's Blue Gene/L machine, surpassing Japan's NEC Earth Simulator. The new machine will reach speeds up to 70.72 teraflops and will be used for nuclear weapons research and reducing energy consumption. This marks a significant jump in computational speed from the original Cray-1 machine. The Top 500 list of fastest supercomputers is announced every six months using a Linpack benchmark. Silicon Graphics' Columbia supercomputer took second place with an impressive 42.7 trillion calculations per second. The Earth Simulator, previously in first place, now holds third position and will continue to model climate and seismic activity.

Other top contenders include Silicon Graphics' Columbia supercomputer and the Earth Simulator from Japan.

The Top 500 list features supercomputers globally every six months using Linpack calculations for speed; Blue Gene/L will surpass current prototypes in power and is expected to significantly enhance nuclear weapons research safety and efficiency. Silicon Graphics' Columbia, a Linux-based system at NASA's Ames Research Center, ranks second with top speeds of 42.7 teraflops, used for aerospace and climate modeling.

Once completed, Blue Gene/L will be four times more powerful and aid in nuclear weapons testing without underground trials. In second place is SGI's Columbia at Ames Research Center with a speed of 42.7 trillion calculations per second. The defeated Japanese Earth Simulator remains in third place for climate modeling and seismic simulation. US supercomputing speeds have increased by 500,000 times since the first Cray-1 installed in 1976.

The Columbia supercomputer at NASA's Ames Research Center in California is second in speed, while Japan's Earth Simulator fell off the top spot after losing out to the Blue Gene/L machine installed at Los Alamos National Laboratory in 2005.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The US has surpassed Japan as the world's top supercomputer based on IBM's Blue Gene/L prototype, currently being assembled for Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory under the US Department of Energy. This machine, scheduled for completion in 2005, will reach speeds of 70.72 teraflops, surpassing Japan's previous top-ranked NEC Earth Simulator (35.86 teraflops). The Top 500 list, updated every six months using the Linpack test for computational speed, now ranks these supercomputers alongside Silicon Graphics' Columbia (42.7 trillion calculations per second) and the deposed Earth Simulator. Blue Gene/L will aid in analyzing nuclear weapons stockpile safety without underground testing and reduce heat generation from massive power consumption. Since 1976, US supercomputers have seen a 500,000-fold increase in speed, with the upcoming Blue Gene/L projected to be five million times faster than the first Cray-1 (80 megaflops). The Top 500 list is determined by international computer science academics and presented at the International Supercomputer Conference.
